reviewText:
As a projectile fighting game Lethal Leagues core is simple: hit your opponent with a ball to score and ultimately win a match.
You can try a bare bones prototype on reptile games' website to see if you like that concept.
Like many other recent small competitive games this one challenges the player with high risk&reward as a single hit from the ball is a knock out. Although if you or your team hit the ball last it won't harm you.
The intense fun of this game starts to kick in once you've hit the ball back and forth a few times, ever increasing its speed to ridiculously high levels (speedometer at the bottom on the boombox). Normal hits only increase the ball speed by 1, charged hits and smashes however double the speed. With more speed the hit lag will increase, the screen will shake, the background will change, intense visual effects will ripple across the screen and the characters will throw catchy phrases at each other as they hit the ball. Next to jumping and swinging you can also bunt the ball to slightly decrease the speed and carefuly set up your next attack.
The movement mechanics are very solid. You can move right and left as you jump, you can tap for a short hop or hold to jump higher and stay in the air longer as well as press down to fall faster.
The selectable characters two major mechanic differences are their method of gaining height (high jump, wall jump, double jump, wall ride, ...) and their special move, which can be activated with a full special bar (builds up by hitting the ball).

Next to online and local multiplayer with up to 4 people there is also a single player challenge with 10 increasingly difficult stages to beat in sequence and in local multiplayer there are 7 levels of AI difficulty with the highest one still being a challenge even if you are already very good at the game - although not as engaging as a good human player will probably be.

And it's a damn lot of fun.
Raced to the top of my most played game ever list during beta testing.

reviewText:
Lethal League is a 2D fighting game, but unlike traditional fighting games you don‚Äôt use fists or kicks or any kind of combat moves. You pick a character and hit an anti-gravity ball against your opponents to beat them, the ball speeds up and bounces harder off the walls with every hit it takes, reaching unbelievably fast speeds - particularly when one charges the hit. All this makes it hard to avoid the ball and also hard to hit the ball. Each player has a certain amount of lives per round and lose them by getting hit with the ball. Once all your lives run out you‚Äôre done, and the round ends when there‚Äôs only one player left in the game.


Pros:
++++ The game is good fast-paced fun, the latency is very comfortable.
+++ The audio and visual aspects are very befitting of each other, especially the effects and art style.
+++ Music is awesome, fits perfectly with the battle atmosphere.
++++ Hitting the ball feels solid, firm ‚Äì making for immersive projectile battles.
++ Different modes: FFA, TEAM DEATHMATCH
+++ Different characters make for different moves/special moves.
+++++ ‚ÄùNo weak ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.‚Äù


Bittersweet:
-/+ Gameplay is easy to learn but hard to get good at, practice makes perfect and provides hours of fun.
-/+ Speed cap for the ball is ridiculously high, might as well be infinite which makes for difficult but impressive moments.
-/+ Limited player choice, however they are very stylish and have different colour schemes.
-/+ Player base has cool people, but it‚Äôs not very big.


Cons:
-Not really anything negative about the game, if I had to name something it would be the lack of characters and small community.



Final Opinion:
All in all this game is addictive, exhilarating and a massive amount of fun. It‚Äôs as if Super Smash Bros, Pong, and whichever traditional 2D fighting game you can think of had a baby. Easy to pick up, hard to master. Art style, music and gameplay go perfectly well together for an amazing fighting experience.

reviewText:
Video Review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MKblaXVby5A&feature=youtu.be

HISTORY

Released in August 2014 and developed by Team Reptile and based off the flash game prototype bearing the same name, it‚Äôs Lethal League!
As of this review the game is on version 1.07.12

STORY AND WHAT YOU DO

In Lethal League with no real context or story, you play as up to 6 different playable characters who face off against each other in an arena in up 4 players at once, the goal simply being to hit the ball at one another to knock them out.

With each consecutive hit to the ball, it gains speed, which can make things very interesting, very fast.

The game also has a number of different modes from online, to versus, to an extra menu with different things such as a tutorial, training mode, as well as the challenge mode which basically acts as the core single player aspect to the game itself.



THE GOOD
-Quick and easy to pick up and play gameplay
-Addicting
-Different game modes and options to choose from
-Competitive and great multiplayer

Right off the BAT pun intended, one of the best aspects to Lethal League is the pick up and play nature of the game itself, it‚Äôs easy to learn and you‚Äôll be smashing your opponents in no time flat, the game features an easy to learn tutorial to help new comers out, but the concept itself is pretty easy to wrap your head around.

It‚Äôs also extremely addicting, the first time me and my friends started playing this together we couldn‚Äôt stop, the quick matches and nature of the game itself lends to the addiction factor big time and it works beautifully.

The gameplay itself is fairly unique, almost reminding of pong on steroids with a gorgeous art style and blazing soundtrack to boast its intensity, the game is easy to play, but definitely takes some serious skill and good timing to master it.

But easily the BEST aspect to Lethal League is the online multiplayer, whether you‚Äôre in a team or free for all, Lethal League truly shines when you‚Äôre pitted against your friends as you battle it out and make the ball reach absolute insane levels of speed.

You‚Äôve also got access to a variety of different game options if you‚Äôre hosting, from changing the speed of the ball itself when you hit it, to a big ball mode, team versus matches, free for all, and a mode where you basically have to hit the opposing team‚Äôs target at each end of the map to gain points.

The character roster as well all have their own unique abilities as well to mix things up, and you unlock different skins for them as you progress the game and earn ‚Äúexperience‚Äù allowing you to level up and unlock the different skins for them and overall really adds to the addictive nature and replayability of the game.

Over all, we had TONS of fun playing this for hours on end and is easily one of the best competitive games I‚Äôve played in recent memory.



THE BAD
-Few core game modes to choose from (not much content) *Minor*

Honestly I don‚Äôt have much to talk about here, Lethal League does what it does very well, I had no major issues or never felt something was unfair or over powered and the game is very well balanced.

Probably the only issue I have is the lack of content, despite just talking about the different game modes to choose from, Lethal League outside of what I mentioned doesn‚Äôt offer much for core game modes.

If you‚Äôre looking for some beefy single player content, you won‚Äôt really find it here, sure you‚Äôve got a versus mode where you can pit yourself against the PC at different difficulty settings, as well as a challenge mode that you can beat with each character to gain some achievements but honestly this felt nowhere near as compelling or interesting as the multiplayer.

As for the multiplayer, once you‚Äôve played as each specific character, and played the different maps and fiddled around with the match settings a bit, you‚Äôve pretty much seen everything this game has to offer you.
But to be honest, this is all pretty minor and I can easily see myself coming back to play this.



THE UGLY
-Not graphically impressive, it‚Äôs quite literally based off a flash game after all
-What it lacks in graphical fidelity it more than makes up for it in art style
-Amazing soundtrack
-Odd game crash during multiplayer

Where we discuss the graphics, soundtrack, and technical aspect of the game.
Lethal League won‚Äôt wow you in the sense with amazing textures and particle effects like some games might, which is obvious considering the game looks like something you could find on Newgrounds.

But what it will wow you with is the fabulous art style it boasts, from the different scenic backgrounds, to the character models and general presentation, what Lethal League lacks in big budget impressive graphics, it more than makes up for in its amazing art style and presentation.
And one thing that really adds to this is the AMAZING soundtrack, this is easily one of the best sound tracks I‚Äôve listened to in a game in a long time, the art style and soundtrack over all give me almost a Jet Set Radio vibe, and I love it.

However, not everything is perfect, we did have our fair number of freezing issues during online matches, as well as the odd game crash or two in my 5 or so hours I‚Äôve spent with Lethal League, but overall the gameplay itself was bug free during our experience and most of the crashes and freezing were during the online match making.



FINAL THOUGHTS

As I said earlier this is probably the most fun I‚Äôve had yet so far with any indie game and I highly recommend you give Lethal League a try if you‚Äôve got some friends looking for a fun, unique, and competitive game, despite some minor technical issues we had, playing this was an absolute blast.

There are many games which have multiplayer mode and only a number of them ends up as global hits which are played by lots of players and in which connection issues are rarity or aren't issues at all. While this game isn't this kind of title yet, I need to say this game is a little gem which should shine really bright in near future. But let's start from the beginning.

Lethal League is a game where your main goal is to control ball and hit it as hard as possible to hurt your opponents and knock them down, while also using unique techniques limited to each of playable characters. Sounds simple, right ? But I assure you it's not that easy, especially when the movement with which ball move after few hits may reach RIDICULOUS speed and hitting the ball itself (or counter it by pressing X which is a kind of a block which stops the movement of it) may be a really tough challenge. This game will test your dexterity, reaction time and timing, which are really crucial here. So in other words I would call this title easy to learn (it's literally jump, hit and block buttons), but hard to fully master.

Graphics are as simple as in screenshots, but I need to say they are still estethic and look nice with bright colors mixed in (I also like in overall the style game brings with interesting characters). And I need to mention one more thing, which is really, REALLY crucial - music. My gosh, music in this one is one of the best things I heard in gaming history. Electronic climates created by really talented artists like Grillo, zeroSCAR or Klaus Veen fits the climate of the game perfectly, while being perfectly well made. I would say music alone in this game make this game worth to purchase, it's THAT good.

To sum it up game is really well made flash-like game with incredible competitive potential. Game basics are simple to learn, but this game has this crucial element, which make it fun, challenging and mostly work like some sort of a drug, which forces you to play it as much as you can. I give it 9,5/10 as I feel 5 characters is kind of a small numbers of possible options if you ask me. But I assure you - this one will become one of the best gaming hits ever. At least it has great potential to become one.

reviewText:
Lethal League (LL) is the quintessence of competitive arcade gameplay. Being completely free of over complication, Team Reptile have fortunately channelled the most special elements of the nostalgic games of the golden era, where a sole focus on gameplay has driven design and development. The result being a game with no apparent story, not character progression, and no cheap ways of making you feel as though you should be playing the game, instead it slaps you in the face with a fresh take on Fighters, that is plain and simply, unsullied fun.

The gameplay and structure of LL lends itself perfectly to the resolution of longstanding disagreements (1-on-1 Fights), bouts of personal worth and glory (4 way FFA), and also to bond-building exercises (2-on-2 Team Fights). The beautiful thing about the simple gameplay is it works so well not only in the hectic 4-way FFA, but also in 1-on-1 combat, where the simple mechanics eventually boil down to a game of whits, where you are more trying to force the other player/s to swing at the wrong point, or you are trying to think and act fast enough to catch them off-guard.

That long winded jargon can be distilled down to; this game is perfect for playing with friends, and that is exactly how it should be consumed. This game has one of those qualities where if you get served too hard, you will hate it; so take it in with friends and you will instantly see the gratifying outcome of learning together, while also pulling off some badass manoeuvres resulting in you all squealing like manly Girl Scouts. We have not tried it in Online Play as my internet services would make the game run like an interactive slideshow. But we can safely say that by grabbing a few ales, a few controllers, and huddling around your PC, you will be parting in the finest display of competition I have seen in a video games since Mario Party 64.

Team Reptile have not given this game a huge amount of content, with 5 characters and 6 Levels, BUT, the content in the game is so perfectly polished, I question whether the development team is really as small as they say. We would love to see more playable characters and levels in the future just to give the game that bit of spice, but where it stands now is a testament to where AAA game development falls short in modern game development; where such heavy focus on being the next money making machine makes games lose that‚Ä¶specialness.

From a developer‚Äôs standpoint this game has soul, you can feel the love that went into it when you play it. So get it, you won‚Äôt be disappointed.

3 / 3 Worth Playing

-C

reviewText:
IntroductionHave you ever wondered what it would be like for superheroes (or beings with superpowers) to play various sports? Perhaps dodgeball? Or baseball? No doubt they would take things to a new extreme, with smashes that break the laws of physics and reaction speeds at mere fractions of milliseconds.

Lethal League is a little like that. Imagine Super Smash Brothers but on PC and instead of fighting, you're essentially playing dodgeball in a fairly small arena. Things can get real chaotic, but boy is it fun!

GameplayLethal League combines sport, with a highly competitive and slightly strategic game that requires you to have good timing, or a good understanding of angles. This does not mean it's a math or physics game. It simply means Lethal League has an extremely high skill ceiling whilst having a very low barrier to entry. Anyone can pick this up with their friends or play vs bots and have a really great time, and those with the best reaction times can duke it out for the top spots.

Your goal is to eliminate all your opponents, by hitting the ball into them. The standard game mode allows you to tag the ball which puts it in your colour and makes it pass through you (so that you don't hit yourself). You can also disable ball tagging for a much more challenging experience. Each time you hit the ball, it goes a little faster. You can hit it up or down depending on whether you are in the air or on the ground. If you smash a ball (air hit) the ball speed is doubled. Now this is where the real fun comes in. If you manage to get 3 or more smashes in, the ball speed is going to ramp up so fast that it quickly becomes a blur of lines in various angles. This is where a knowledge of angles can help you to overcome your opponent.

The maximum speed seems to be capped at 1 million. As you break through known speed limits, your hits gradually have a longer delay but the ball speed is so fast that it becomes ALMOST impossible to react to it. You're likely going to struggle with this until you learn the timing windows for various hits, and it is oh so satisfying to counter a ball ping-ponging across the room at over 100,000 (whatever the speed measurement is) into your opponent.

You can also bunt the ball in various directions, temporarily slowing it down and allowing you to regain control and possibly change its direction. This is used in combination with regular hits to quickly rack up speed or pull off an unexpectedly fast smash, because bunting a ball reduces the delay on a hit (even the insanely fast ones that require 2-4 seconds of delay) to almost nothing.

Characters
There are 6 characters to choose from and each of them have distinct strengths and weaknesses. Some of them can jump higher than others, some can jump off walls indefinitely etc. This alone would make it fun, however the devs decided this is not enough so they added special abilities. Where do I even begin? Special abilities can drastically change the course of a match in an instant! By hitting the ball you gain charges of your special meter. At 4 charges you can use the ability by double tapping the regular hitting button. Each character has their own unique move that you'll discover on your own, and it adds so much more fun to the game along with previously mentioned elements.

VisualsThe visual style of this game is unique, but still quite simple. Characters have some lovely color variations and stages are fairly well designed.

AudioI absolutely love the music in this game, as well as the other assorted sounds in the game. When you break the sound barrier, the hit sounds are so impactful and sound like rockets or small bombs going off.

Other ThoughtsRunning at 60 FPS is pretty much required to be able to learn your timings properly. The first time I ran the game, it had some very weird frame drops that may have been an issue on my side, but it initially turned me off from the game. However subsequent play sessions did not have that issue, so it must have been some other unrelated issue. The game is very lightweight and runs flawlessly.

I would have liked to see more characters in the game, as 6 is hardly a roster of characters compared to other games in this kind of genre. I mean not even the Scout from TF2? That's an iconic character that would have been perfect here.

SummaryLethal League is the type of game you can pick up at any time and play with friends. Even as a solo player, you'll find that the bots are quite challenging, and there's enough single player content to keep you interested for even a couple days. The gamplay is fun and rewarding, and is definitely worth checking out if you're interested in a fun, fast, sport-action game.

8/10 - The game that destroys friendships

reviewText:
Lethal League is a what you get when you cross a fighting game with dodgeball in all the best ways.  Players jockey to control a small ball, hitting it around the screen in an attempt to knock out eachother.  Every hit on the ball speeds it up, and it quickly moves from an easy to predict slow moving projectile to a streak that bounces around the screen, ricocheting off ceiling, walls, and floor to take out players.

This simple set up leads to an exciting and incredibly fun game.  Unlike most fighting games, there are no long lists of special moves to learn and memorize (each character has slightly differnt angles they will hit the ball at, and a special move that can be powered up during play and used, but no difficult button combos are required for any moves).  This makes the game very intuitive and easy for players to jump in and start playing, even if you are not into fighters.  However, the interplay between player and their specials does lead to a suprising amount of depth in the combat, and learning the timing to intercept balls as they come off of other players at higher speeds will take practice.

If I had any criticisms for the game, it would be that the simplicity of it can be a double edged sword.  Games can start feeling repetative during long play sessions.  Game options can extend this a bit, but in the end most feel gimicky and I find myself losing interest after 30-60 minutes.  However, that being said, I still find myself coming back to this game to get in a few quick rounds against friends when we don't have time for a long playsession, or to finish out a night of gaming.  And that is where the game shines imho, quick bursts of action and excitement when I don't have the time to spend hours playing.

This games perfectly fills a niche in my gaming library.  It is well worth the price (and worth getting a few extra copies for your friends as well).  An unreserved thumbs up from me.

If you like brawl games (i.e: super smash bros), then this should be an automatic pickup. Great party game, simple yet deep gameplay, and great potential for mindgames and trickery at high levels of play once all the mechanics have been mastered. Be warned however, if you do not live in North America, South America or Europe you might struggle to find a game that isn't laggy if you venture into online multiplayer. If the lag passes a certain threshold, then a crash to the main menu is all but guaranteed. Trying to play too far outside of your continent's peak time (seems to be 8-10pm here in Europe) is an exercise in futility.

Pros:
- Perfect controller support
- Engaging, simple and deep gameplay.
- The community is eager to teach each other tricks, timings, openers, etc, making the learning curve much easier if you ask for help.
- Low skill floor, high skill ceiling.
- Very challenging singleplayer challenge mode.
- Singleplayer, multiplayer and local multiplayer modes.

Cons:
- Lag can become a serious issue if playing with people from a different continent.
- Tutorial leaves a lot to be desired. It misses one of the most important aspects of counter-play (the parry).
- Does not allow you to set a resolution in windowed mode (my biggest gripe with the game).
- Bots lack any non-essential movement (hitting corpses, moving back and forth to add extra visual noise, pre-positioning), making fights against them feel very static compared to players.
- Matchmaking in its current incarnation does not put you into a lobby that has already played a game and has no 2v2 option, making organizing games via steam community chat much better than the quick match" button.

reviewText:
Ok, so first of all, some people think that the actual content that this game offers doesn't really justify it's price. I don't share this opinion, the game isn't really all that expensive and while the content may be limited, there is just a lot of fun to be had with it. However, I still strongly urge anyone who considers buying Lethal League to get some friends to play this game with and buy a 2 or a 4-pack and split the price. The multipacks are pretty good deals, and the game is the most fun when you are playing it with a friend anyway.

Now that we got that out of the way, let's talk about why you should buy this game, because you absolutely should.

Lethal League is a projectile based 2-D fighter with an interesting, kind of jet-set-like style to it. It features a surprisingly good soundtrack that really complements the gameplay as well as the overall feel of the game. Lethal League actually has very few mechanics, yet still provides a decent amount of depth, so it is pretty easy to pick up while being able to entertain and challenge you for a long amount of time.

Basically, the goal in this game is to hit your opponent with an anti-gravity-ball which will cause them to lose one life instantly. You can hit or bunt the ball in various fashions to make it reach ludicrious speeds and bounce around in crazy patterns, and believe me, it's just mad fun. The sheer insanity of the gameplay paired with the incredible soundtrack and cool visual just makes it a blast to watch or play.

There are currently six characters which differ in mobility and special moves, as well as the angles they can make the ball travel at.
The game doesn't really offer all that interesting offline modes, but it's most enjoyable in multyplayer anyway. You can play free for alls, team fights and 1v1s. Lethal League, just like Skullgirls, uses GGPO and it results in super smooth feeling online play.

So, if the concept sounds at least a bit appealing to you and you have someone to play it with, you really owe yourself to pick it up, especially since there are not much games that are able to offer you a similar expierence out there.

reviewText:
The best way to describe Lethal League is as a simplification of the fighter genre mixed with a projectile game.

Divekick did that in that fact that instead of having complicated moves, it became more about timing and mind games.

Lethal League does that in your positioning, your timing (although its pretty easy to get good at that), and your ability to change things up enough to freak out the opponent. If you don't mess with their head, and you're both good at the timing and positioning, the game can go on for a long time.

It's a lot about making less mistakes than the other person. In fact, that's pretty much how you win.

But enough about that, why should you play this game?

PROS:
- Easy to just play, easy to get good at, but relatively hard to get REALLY good at
- Can keep you busy with just the singleplayer, but has a decent online matchmaking system, as well as local and online 4 player, similar to smash bros
- Good at not frustrating the player, the most fun way to play if the best way to win
- Gameplay that manages to be fast but also slow??? It works, trust me
- Awesome music
- Funky art
- No weak ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•

CONS:
- Small character roster (Also a pro because it's easier to learn everything)
- Much lower skill cap than other fighters (doesn't mean it can't be competetive)
- Really grindy level up system (at least you get rewards for every level in the form of colour palletes and different balls which change up gameplay)

In short, if you like unique fighters, or Jet Set Radio, or both (like me), this game should be appealing to you.
Also a good party game. Not that I'd know.

reviewText:
TL;DR Buy this game.


This game is simple yet very entertaining, a game in which you hit a ball and try to get it to hit your opponent.

The game utilizes a very simple control scheme consisting of the following: Up, Down, Left, and Right, Attack, Jump, and Bunt.

U/D/L/R Does exactly what you think it does, but can also be used for aiming the ball when hitting it.
Attack will swing your character's tool of choice after a tiny delay (swing up time) in either the direction you are facing, or Down/Up if you aimed it.
Bunting will significantly slow the ball down for a brief amount of time, making the ball act more like a real ball (following gravity until it gets hit or touches a wall)
Jumping is self-explanatory, however if you do a down attack on the ball while jumping, you will double the ball speed.

The ball does not follow the laws of physics, and instead acts more like you'd expect a ball from pong to do.

There's a slight catch when hitting the ball however, as when it gets faster, there will be a delay between when you make contact with the ball and when the ball gets released, indicated by a 'power' bar near the speedometer. This is essential for timing some of the faster balls (i.e. ball speeds in the 20000+ range as at that point you cannot rely on reaction times, as the ball is now more like a laser beam) and adds to the game's mechanics a bit more. This is called hit-lag. If you bunt the ball then hit it while it is still purple, the ball will instantly launch with no hit-lag. Some powerups can circumvent hitlag as well. During hit-lag, you are immobile.

During hit-lag, the non attacking player can wait for the ball to near the end of hit-lag, jump up, and use the timer to time hitting the ball. To combat this, the player that is hit-lagged can use the bunt ability to shield the ball near the end of the hit-lag. This will prevent players from hitting it right after it comes out of hit-lag, and will severly punish them as once they do hit it, they will be knocked back and most likely get hit by it. Avoid using this with friends, as they may regard it as cheap.

The stages are roomy but not too big as to feel unfair. All stages have a consistent size. More on stages later.

With the mechanics out of the way, it's time to get to the characters. I'm going to summarize them in my own words, as the developer's words can be found on their website.

You got Raptor. Sporty baseball kid, his tool of choice is a baseball bat. He can hop off of walls to gain more height, and his special move is to hit the ball twice, which is activated simply by double tapping the attack button. When he does this action, he can change the direction of the ball, and also it circumvents hit-lag.

Then you have Switch, a rebellious skateboarding robot who hits the ball with his skateboard. He can ride up walls (and on the ceiling), and his special ability is being able to hit the ball if it is under him, which is activated by hitting jump while already in the air. His ability ignores hit-lag.

Next, candyman. A tap dancing dandy with a big yellow ball of candy as a head, he uses his cane to hit the ball, and his special ability allows the ball to go through walls and appear on the other side of the level. Activated by attacking twice when hitting the ball. His jump is very high.

Also, you have Sonata. A very strong girl who wields a powerful bass-hammer just to show off her strength. She can double jump, and her special ability allows her to control and change the ball's direction three times after activating it by attacking twice. Good for either making the ball dodge the enemy player's swings, or getting the ball in a hard to hit place (i.e. at the very bottom, or just a little bit above headlevel).

Finally, you have Latch. Genetically modified crocodile, he can grab onto and climb walls and he uses his tail to smack the ball. His special ability is the ability to store the ball in his mouth, allowing him to move while under the effects of hitlag, and also be extremely confusing as to what position he will release the ball in.

Soon, there will be an additional charcter (DICE) and I'll have to update this.


Now, onto stages.
There are 6 stages.

A purple-ish desert (seen in the title card)
An almost empty pool with a futuristic backdrop
A sewer
A padded cell
A train, that moves across futuristic buildings
And a dark street near an APC type vehicle.

All of these have a seperate and appropriate banging tune to go along with the action.
I find myself often listening to the music outside of the game, as the soundtrack is really solid, and in my opinion without it the game would be a lot worse.

All in all, this game is easily my GOTY. I've already gotten almost 20 hours of enjoyment out of it so far, and I've yet to get anywhere near bored of the game. And it's only ~$25 after tax for a two pack, so grab one for yourself and a friend and fight.

The controls are all really solid, no matter if it's a keyboard or a controller or a weird gamepad from 2005 that lacks analog sticks. The game handles well with all controls.

Networking is pretty solid as well, with you being able to choose smooth visuals with an input delay (if latency is high) or a slowed down game with no input delay. I prefer the former, as it's far easier to adapt to.

The only thing that I don't like about the game is the current lack of variety in stages/characters, as you can blow through all stages and characters pretty quickly. But obviously in the future this won't be true (hopefully)

In summary,

PROS:
*Simple control scheme that leads to intense gameplay
*Solid networking
*Amazing art direction and soundtrack
*Good cast of characters
*No weak ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•

CONS:
*Lack of variety

Definitely my pick for the most fun to be had in a game in several years! Lethal League is a projectile fighting game which starts off easy to learn, then quickly scales into either a chaotic mess of fun to be had with your friends or a very interesting competitive experience. It being a multiplayer game, it does suffer from the usual lack of opponents issue when you want to play against someone in less than ideal circumstances. The art of the game certainly isn't particularly striking or unique in any way, just enough so to serve its purpose. Lethal League also suffers from a lack of diverse content, but that's forgivable as what content there is has been polished to a mirror shine.

reviewText:
Lethal League is a fantastic fighting game that shines at its brightest with friends due to its accessibility, complexity, and consistency in providing incredible moments during matches. It plays like a fast-paced and dangerous game of ping pong and dodgeball where the ball will knock the stuffing out of you if you're hit.

The accessibility comes from the simple concept of hitting the ball is good while being hit by the ball is bad. The tutorial  (located in EXTRAS) will take you through the basics and teach you enough to start smacking the ball around in different directions in different ways. You'll be exposed to the basic attack which adds only one speed to the ball, a charge up attack which can add up to x2 the current speed of the ball, and the down smash which always doubles the speed of the ball. You'll also be introduced to bunting which pops the ball up into the air no matter how fast it's going, your special which is usually the attack button during hit lag/pause (that freezing moment before you release the ball), and the jump button. You can also taunt or taunt + direction to emote.

The complexity comes from all the subtleties found within the game. Each character has their own special moveset in regards to how they move, jump, and control their special. For example, Sonata has a double jump, Candyman have a floaty jump that reaches the top of the screen, while Latch can jump onto and then climb up and down walls. You can clash with other players resulting in one or both being stunned, bunt attacks, bunt bunts, control the direction of bunts, adjust your attacking angles, reduce the hitlag/pause by bunting before performing an air down smash or a charge attack so your opponent can't counter easily, and so on to the point that there are some helpful guides in the Community Hub that can improve your game once you're ready.

As for moments, there are so many. One of my favorites happen to be this one match where I exchanged a ball going at 1,000,000 speed several times with a worthy opponent. Keep in mind the ball starts off at a default speed of 8 unless you change the settings. Here's a video showing some three player gameplay with different settings: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zexKK2TYI-Y

Finally, I'll mention the settings because you can drastically change the approach of how to play depending on what you choose. The game has two modes that I know of, stocks (think SSB) and points. Stocks rewards the player who's able to stay alive. Points rewards the player that can attain the most kills/knockouts. Ball tagging on means you don't have to fear the ball you just hit while turning it off means it's a danger to everyone at all times. You can also change the ball if you're at a high enough level. So far I've only played with the Big Ball which seems to have a bigger hitbox and a longer hit lag. You can also set the time limit or turn it off if in case you want to play for the most kills in five minutes or first to twelve kills.

P.S. Play with friends or people. It's much, much less fun to play against the AI. You can use the in-game matchmaking or peeking in the Community Hub chat to find pick-up games if you don't have a group of friends for ball smashing.

Lethal League knocks it out of the park, without even trying. The mechanics to this fighter are straightforward and very easy to understand. Two to four characters hit a baseball around an arena, trying to hit the other players with it. If a player hits the ball back, the speed of the ball increases. You can ‚Äúbunt‚Äù the ball, temporarily knocking it straight up, but once it‚Äôs hit again or touches the ground it will resume its previous velocity. If a player manages to hit the ball four times, they can do a special move that varies by character.

It sounds simplistic on paper, but the ball velocity gets so high that your only view of it is as a straight line bisection the arena. Timing is critical, strategy vital, and seat-of-your-pants tactics (wild panic works too) all combine into a high-octane fight unlike anything I‚Äôve seen before. In a very strange, oblique way, it reminds me of high-level play in Rockstar‚Äôs Table Tennis. Lethal League has even replaced Soul Calibur as my favorite fighting game.

If you‚Äôre curious about the game, you can play the original prototype of Lethal League here: http://lethalleague.reptile-games.com/prototype/ - it‚Äôs not quite the same as the full game, but it‚Äôs enough to give you a good impression.

How do I describe this game?.......
Lethal leauge is how many peopke describe it, a mix between PONG and Super Smash Bros. The main idea is you and up to 3 other players hit a small ball that seems to lack gravity or air resistance inbetween each other. When you hit the ball it get's 'tagged' with your color, and if someone gets hit with the ball when it's not tagged their color they're out.

There's a lot more to it than that, like stage sizes and hit angles, but if you want a fun little game you ca jump into whenever and mess around with friends, or compete in actual tournaments, this game is for you.

Overall, I give this game a 10/10. Really. I have no complaints.

reviewText:
What can I say about Lethal League that hasn't already been said? It's a fantastic game, and one worth playing for quite a while! Team Reptile did an amazing job with this title, ranging from the excellent gameplay, to the beautiful soundtrack, even to the art the game displays so well. Let's have a jawbreaker and take a look, shall we?

Intro: Lethal League is a game that will test you and make sure you make the right decisions, or you're going to strike out fast! The aim of the game is to smack a ball and try to hit your opponent with it to knock him out, which makes him lose a piece of health. Everytime you hit the ball it turns your color so you can't get hit until he hits it back! You play as one of six total characters: Raptor, Switch, Candyman, Sonata, Latch, and Dice. Each character hits the ball in different angles and has their own jump heights and abilities that make each of them stand out from one another. You've got your basic 15 year old baseball player, all the way down to a cyborg crocodile that uses his tail to hit the ball and a robot with a skateboard!

Gameplay: The gameplay in Lethal League is absolutely amazing. It is so fun making the ball go thousands of miles per hour and always wondering if you'll hit the ball, or be hit yourself! You have some options of hitting the ball, such as doing a downward smash that doubles the ball speed, or just hitting it straight forward to try to trick your opponent into thinking it'll go somewhere else. Characters fill up a four bar meter everytime they hit the ball, and when full they can use their special attack which can do things like make the ball travel through walls or just eat it and spit it back out! The fun in Lethal League is the simplicity of it, and while simple, it is incredibly fun and satisfying.

Music: Music in any game is usually why I keep playing. Lethal League's soundtrack is some of the greatest in indie game music that I've heard. Team Reptile really hit it out of the park with this one, and there was not one single song I disliked in this title. The menu music alone is just phenomenal, and tracks like Ordinary Days and Scream just add to the awesomeness of it. They all loop pretty nicely and sound very well done. The soundtrack in Lethal League will surely not disappoint you at all!

Graphics: Lethal League overall looks pretty good for an indie game. The art of the characters is pretty sweet, and so are the backgrounds of each stage. It's also amazing to look at the stages changes the faster you hit the ball, and I feel just makes it way more satisfying to reach insane speeds! The animations feel a bit clunky and weird though, but not something that I really payed much attention to. I will say though, if you want a headache then go ahead and play this game for hours, as it will probably hurt your eyes!

Conclusion: I most likely missed some elements and whatnot but I really only wanted to touch on those three topics. That being said, this is a game you MUST play. I recommend it for everyone who loves fighting games and playing with friends. To have the best experience, please do grab some friends and enjoy the hell out of this game! You might not like the 14 dollar price on this game, and that is reasonable due to how simple the game is, but it is worth the money. If you can get some friends, then no doubt you'll be hitting homeruns in no time!

Rating: 9/10

reviewText:
What can I say about Lethal League that hasn't already been said? It's a fantastic game, and one worth playing for quite a while! Team Reptile did an amazing job with this title, ranging from the excellent gameplay, to the beautiful soundtrack, even to the art the game displays so well. Let's have a jawbreaker and take a look, shall we?

Intro: Lethal League is a game that will test you and make sure you make the right decisions, or you're going to strike out fast! The aim of the game is to smack a ball and try to hit your opponent with it to knock him out, which makes him lose a piece of health. Everytime you hit the ball it turns your color so you can't get hit until he hits it back! You play as one of six total characters: Raptor, Switch, Candyman, Sonata, Latch, and Dice. Each character hits the ball in different angles and has their own jump heights and abilities that make each of them stand out from one another. You've got your basic 15 year old baseball player, all the way down to a cyborg crocodile that uses his tail to hit the ball and a robot with a skateboard!

Gameplay: The gameplay in Lethal League is absolutely amazing. It is so fun making the ball go thousands of miles per hour and always wondering if you'll hit the ball, or be hit yourself! You have some options of hitting the ball, such as doing a downward smash that doubles the ball speed, or just hitting it straight forward to try to trick your opponent into thinking it'll go somewhere else. Characters fill up a four bar meter everytime they hit the ball, and when full they can use their special attack which can do things like make the ball travel through walls or just eat it and spit it back out! The fun in Lethal League is the simplicity of it, and while simple, it is incredibly fun and satisfying.

Music: Music in any game is usually why I keep playing. Lethal League's soundtrack is some of the greatest in indie game music that I've heard. Team Reptile really hit it out of the park with this one, and there was not one single song I disliked in this title. The menu music alone is just phenomenal, and tracks like Ordinary Days and Scream just add to the awesomeness of it. They all loop pretty nicely and sound very well done. The soundtrack in Lethal League will surely not disappoint you at all!

Graphics: Lethal League overall looks pretty good for an indie game. The art of the characters is pretty sweet, and so are the backgrounds of each stage. It's also amazing to look at the stages changes the faster you hit the ball, and I feel just makes it way more satisfying to reach insane speeds! The animations feel a bit clunky and weird though, but not something that I really payed much attention to. I will say though, if you want a headache then go ahead and play this game for hours, as it will probably hurt your eyes!

Conclusion: I most likely missed some elements and whatnot but I really only wanted to touch on those three topics. That being said, this is a game you MUST play. I recommend it for everyone who loves fighting games and playing with friends. To have the best experience, please do grab some friends and enjoy the hell out of this game! You might not like the 14 dollar price on this game, and that is reasonable due to how simple the game is, but it is worth the money. If you can get some friends, then no doubt you'll be hitting homeruns in no time!

Rating: 9/10

Team Reptile did an amazing job with this title, ranging from the excellent gameplay, to the beautiful soundtrack, even to the art the game displays so well. Let's have a jawbreaker and take a look, shall we?

Intro: Lethal League is a game that will test you and make sure you make the right decisions, or you're going to strike out fast! The aim of the game is to smack a ball and try to hit your opponent with it to knock him out, which makes him lose a piece of health. Everytime you hit the ball it turns your color so you can't get hit until he hits it back! You play as one of six total characters: Raptor, Switch, Candyman, Sonata, Latch, and Dice. Each character hits the ball in different angles and has their own jump heights and abilities that make each of them stand out from one another. You've got your basic 15 year old baseball player, all the way down to a cyborg crocodile that uses his tail to hit the ball and a robot with a skateboard!

Gameplay: The gameplay in Lethal League is absolutely amazing. It is so fun making the ball go thousands of miles per hour and always wondering if you'll hit the ball, or be hit yourself! You have some options of hitting the ball, such as doing a downward smash that doubles the ball speed, or just hitting it straight forward to try to trick your opponent into thinking it'll go somewhere else. Characters fill up a four bar meter everytime they hit the ball, and when full they can use their special attack which can do things like make the ball travel through walls or just eat it and spit it back out! The fun in Lethal League is the simplicity of it, and while simple, it is incredibly fun and satisfying.

Music: Music in any game is usually why I keep playing. Lethal League's soundtrack is some of the greatest in indie game music that I've heard. Team Reptile really hit it out of the park with this one, and there was not one single song I disliked in this title. The menu music alone is just phenomenal, and tracks like Ordinary Days and Scream just add to the awesomeness of it. They all loop pretty nicely and sound very well done. The soundtrack in Lethal League will surely not disappoint you at all!

Graphics: Lethal League overall looks pretty good for an indie game. The art of the characters is pretty sweet, and so are the backgrounds of each stage. It's also amazing to look at the stages changes the faster you hit the ball, and I feel just makes it way more satisfying to reach insane speeds! The animations feel a bit clunky and weird though, but not something that I really payed much attention to. I will say though, if you want a headache then go ahead and play this game for hours, as it will probably hurt your eyes!

Conclusion: I most likely missed some elements and whatnot but I really only wanted to touch on those three topics. That being said, this is a game you MUST play. I recommend it for everyone who loves fighting games and playing with friends. To have the best experience, please do grab some friends and enjoy the hell out of this game! You might not like the 14 dollar price on this game, and that is reasonable due to how simple the game is, but it is worth the money. If you can get some friends, then no doubt you'll be hitting homeruns in no time!

Rating: 9/10

reviewText:
I found this really interesting game on YouTube, and it looked appealing. So I waited for a good sale, bought it, and just had a blast. When I first saw this game, I thought it was your average fighting game that you could land all the sweet combos with friends. But Lethal League is so much more than just a fighting game. With the only way to blast fighters out of the arena using a ball that is consitantly gaining speed, bouncing, flying, and who knows what in any direction, this game adds an intense factor in trying to stay alive.

I remember when I had three friends over and we all had out own wired controllers, so I suggested we played Lethal League. I had already been playing a lot of it, and they had never played in their life. Now, when I thought playing alone was fun, I never accounted having friends to play with. But when more people joined the game, it becomes hilariously joyous, with a lot of tense moments of only two people left and the ball being at over 1000 speed, some people figuring out new attacks, or people getting that three-hit wipeout, mostly on accident.

All in all, Lethal League is a sweat-inducing and creative game, bringing a fresh idea to the fighting game genre, and one that works incredibly well. The multiplayer works great, hit detection is fine, the characters are interesting, and the gameplay is just plain awesome.

Review:

Admittedly, this is not a game that has come up on the randomizer.  In fact, I think I have decided that once every nine or ten days I think I am going to play a game of my own choosing, in order to balance out the reviews, and to keep me from going crazy.  So I figure the best way to start off my ‚Äòplayer‚Äôs choice‚Äô series would be Lethal League, a multiplayer smash fest from Team Reptile.  Now, I admitted earlier that I really wasn‚Äôt that big on fighting games, and in fact often just pounded the controller like I was asking for another beer at a crowded bar hoping the other guy walked into my punches.  I confess now that there was one unmentioned exception to that statement, and that was the classic Nintendo 64 version of smash brothers.  I actually spent a significant amount of time refining my skill in that game, partially because it was a fighting game I was actually fairly decent at, but more because it was oodles of fun, and a great game to play with friends.

Fast forward a decade and change, and we have Lethal League, which is a rehashing of the typical multiplayer chaos on the screen everyone pounding controllers while jumping up and down and ‚Äòaccidentally‚Äô kicking each other while playing sort of game, only this time with the added fun of dodgeball rules added in.  See, instead of simply smashing each other directly, players instead knock a little color coded ball back and forth with the goal of hitting someone else, knocking them out until the next serve.  Difficulty is added as the ball‚Äôs speed increases every time it is hit, giving players a reward for timing over button mashing.  Each character even has their own special move, from Dice‚Äôs occasional arcing of the ball over everyone's‚Äô heads to candyman‚Äôs wall-looping trick, each character has a way to frustrate everyone else playing.  And with both online and local multiplayer modes possible, this game will give you enough play value to make it worth any amount of money, and eventual frustration over whoever picks Latch.  Can‚Äôt recommend this one enough, folks.  Have fun!

Game‚Äôs Fate: Kept.  Also installed on the laptop.  Never know when you want another round
Buy/No Buy: Buy.  Heck, Buy a multipack and send it to all your friends.

reviewText:
tl;dr: buy this game.  Heck, buy the four-pack and get some friends in on the action.  You'll have a blast.

This game is an odd mashup of things like Tekken, Super Smash Bros, Pong, and a bit of Dragonball Z mixed in for good measure.  If you get a couple of friends and all play together, this game is one of the best times you'll collectively have.  I haven't played in the open multiplayer so I can't vouch for the online community, but playing against friends is simply fantastic.  The online multiplayer will occasionally desyncronize when starting a match, but it only takes about 10 seconds to exit the game, restart it, host a new lobby, invite your friends into it, and restart.  The desync error also is not particularly common, certainly less than 10% of matches will have this issue.  Not a serious detraction from the overall game.

There are, however, two things missing: a replay system and a spectator mode.  There are many situations where it would be nice to have a replay so you can answer questions like How did that shot hit me?" or "That was an awesome move
date: can I see that again?"  I hope the devs will eventually include some form of replay management.  The inclusion of a spectator mode would make this game viable for some tournaments and casting.  I doubt it'll rival things like LoL or DOTA for popularity
recommended: but at some events it would be great to have a Lethal League tournament going on as a side-attraction or something."

reviewText:
In a dystopian future where baseball is actually entertaining, a skateboarding robot, a deranged candy salesman, and a hipster crocodile battle it out for supremacy.

Lethal league is a fighting game based around the premise of pong. While each character has a special move and the ability to attack one another, the only way to knock out your opponent is by smashing an oversized baseball into them. A deceptively simple premise that turns out to be a lot harder than it sounds, the ball will continue to move faster with each hit making it harder to predict and counter.

Pros
-Shockingly addicting
-Great Sound track
-Decent number of game mods with up to four players (1v1, team battle, ffa, stock/point etc)
-ggpo netcode

Cons
-Not much of a single player (granted it is a fighter)

Definitely worth a buy if you're looking for a quirky fighter to play online or with friends.

reviewText: I don't remember how I was introduced to the prototype, but I shared it with my housemates and we've played hours worth of games over the course of the last six months. The simplicity, the visceral feedback, and the mindgames are what really make this game special. You can learn all the mechanics there is to learn in about 2 minutes, but what really takes a long time is learning how to read your opponent, what they're going to do and how to prepare for you. TotalBiscuit criticised the art style, but I have to disagree with him - The Boombox culture of south central los Angeles personified in cartoon form is a really fresh direction for a game to take. Maybe the palette has been exaggerated and might be a bit noisy, but I'll be damned if every single hit, every single return of the ball with the little flash particle animations isn't an instant dopamine hit.\n\nTL;Dr - simple game with a lot of strategic depth, great music, fresh art, solid mechanics. Recommend to everybody, I hope the guys at Reptile make millions of dollars.

reviewText: I don't remember how I was introduced to the prototype, but I shared it with my housemates and we've played hours worth of games over the course of the last six months. The simplicity, the visceral feedback, and the mindgames are what really make this game special. You can learn all the mechanics there is to learn in about 2 minutes, but what really takes a long time is learning how to read your opponent, what they're going to do and how to prepare for you. TotalBiscuit criticised the art style, but I have to disagree with him - The Boombox culture of south central los Angeles personified in cartoon form is a really fresh direction for a game to take. Maybe the palette has been exaggerated and might be a bit noisy, but I'll be damned if every single hit, every single return of the ball with the little flash particle animations isn't an instant dopamine hit.\n\nTL;Dr - simple game with a lot of strategic depth, great music, fresh art, solid mechanics. Recommend to everybody, I hope the guys at Reptile make millions of dollars.

Lethal league involves hitting a ball into other players. The ball gradually speeds up until it gets to insane high speeds. Unlike most arcade fighter games movement in incredibly important and memorising combos is unnecessary.

Lethal league is graphically and musically stylish and appealing as well as insanely fun.

reviewText:
I got this game on sale quite a while ago - and at that point my only experience was with single-player. I held off on a review, because I would have thumbs-downed it. Why does this title have overwhelmingly positive reviews on Steam?!

It must be played with controllers on a couch with local multiplayer. This is where this game shines. There is alot of screaming and shouting and laughing. Lots of twitching. Great fun.

Pros:
+Excellent concept - bringing such a fresh breath of life to stale fighting games
+Brilliantly simple controls - no tedious combos to memorize
+Characters each have their own specialties - it seems subtle, though
+Music is pretty good

Cons:
-While this game is crazy fun, there is wasted potential at this point IMO, I really think there is TONS of room for expansion, such as:
-Needs more playable characters
-Needs better artwork, IMO
-Needs more playable levels
-Needs more gameplay modes (only 3 right now)

Overall, the fun factor is pretty much through the roof with this title. If you have couch coop opportunities, this is a no brainer.

reviewText:
I usually don't write reviews after only playing for a half hour. I tend to wait until I've either finished the game or played a large enough portion before getting bored with it to come to a valid conclusion.

What I've seen of Lethal League so far indicates that it's a supremely addictive game. Simple mechanics are coupled with a very high skill ceiling and lots of challenge, which over the course of each match escalates to ludicrous heights. Each character has a very different set of abilities beyond simply tossing the ball around and the combination of a variety of characters make on-the-fly strategizing against them very entertaining. Overall I'd give Lethal League a big recommendation on that front.

However, the connection issues are what absolutely kill this game for me at the moment. Every other match doesn't load properly and I've had plenty of disconnects even with players in my own region. Mind you that I have a 15MB/s (that's Megabyte, not Megabit) connection where my PC is connected via Ethernet cable and not Wi-Fi, so my connection is about as solid as you can get, and yet it still fails around 50% of the time. I won't cry about connection times since I realize that they're mostly down to the amount of active players, but once a connection is established, it's amazing how bad the game manages to function. Not to mention that when the game does actually hang up and never starts the next match, you can't simply get out again by pressing Escape or any other keys. You have to terminate the application with Alt+F4 every single time this happens, and it can get very annoying.

I was fortunate enough to have bought the game with the recent Humble Monthly, so it cost me around $1.2, or 90% less than what's asked for here on Steam, which is why I'll keep the game and give it a mild pass in order to see if the issues get resolved in the future. But for the record, had I paid full price, I'd have refunded this broken mess immediately. Which is unfortunate, a game with solid mechanics and the potential for hours of fun is shot in the kneecaps by terrible connection issues.

If the issues get resolved, I will edit this review to reflect any future changes made here.

the gameplay of lethal league is simple you can't really do much you can jump strike and punt. only 3 buttons but the maneuvers you can string together using these 3 buttons are essential to mastering the game. each one of your moves jump, strike, and  punt all have a different functionality depending on the situation and character.each character has a unique jump mechanic such as wall jump double jump ect. all characters have a downward strike will jumping. and all characters have a special move after hitting something 4 times.there are 5 characters so far. switch,raptor,sonata,candyman and latch. learning your characters move set, mobility, and strengths is key to knowing what to do in each situation and really adds depth to the game. my 2 favorite character so far are switch and sonta, switch  can ride on the walls and has a pretty horizontal swing. on the other hand sonata has a double jump and had a pretty vertical swing . each character differences do add some subtly to the game and doesn't change the core gameplay. unlike other fighting game where u have to know each character's inputs and timing this game is all about timing so u can hope on any character pretty much and still be competent. the moment to moment gameplay can look a little daunting to new players but the simple mechanics make it easy to hop in the game and just play and once you start to learn how to predict the ball then thats when you'll really get into the deep nuance  of this game. the developers did a good job of showing you the basic of the gameplay in their tutorial while still giving you the opportunity to discover new game mechanics on your own. overall the gameplay is simple yet hard to master and thats what u want ina competitive game

reviewText:
First Try on Lethal League!

The video can be found here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u7Vc2IthOrY


Lethal League is an interesting take on a projectile based fighting game.

The controls are reduced to their bare minimum, giving you the option to jump, hit and punt, but the timing of these commands is what divides the good from the best. Since the ball can be hit in any angle you want there are a lot of factors to consider on how and when to hit it or if you want to slow the ball down with a punt to smash it more acurrately.

Currently there are 5 playable characters available, which for a launch line-up is okay, but I hope that more characters will be added soon. Each character has its own special ability which you can use when your power meter(I haven't heard an official name for that yet) is full. You can fill your power meter by hitting the ball and when it's full you can release your special ability by pressing the hit button again while you are hitting the ball. What is quite notable as well is that each character has special movment and jumping capabilities. For example, Candyman cannot walljump, therefore he is able to jump higher.

There are also 6 levels, but here are some weakpoints the game has in my opinion. The levels are just backgrounds, there is no real interaction with what is going on in the front. For example there is a level where you are on a street. In the background you see a tank(at least it looks like one to me) and buildings. Wouldn't it be awesome, if these elements would come into play, for example the tank shoots one of the buildings and rubble is coming down and affects the ball or makes you go away from certain areas? At least I would like that.

Another thing is that the graphical fidelity leaves a lot to be desired. While I dig the artstyle that looks like jet-set radio in 2D, the backgrounds just don't really look that good.
What is great though is the animations quality which give you a nice feel of the velocity of the ball and let the controlls feel really good. It also has to be noted that the stop motion moments when hitting a very fast ball are extremely funny and change depending on what level you are currently at.

The game also features a progression system which lets you unlock new colouring for the playable characters.

Last, but not least, let's talk about the soundeffects and the soundtrack. The soundeffects are quite nice and there is a nice variety on sound cues available. The soundtrack itself features different artists. To be honest, it is not my style of music, but I found it really fitting and enjoyable at times.

Having not tried the multiplayer yet, there is one big component missing, but from what I've heard, the netcode is working fine, only disconnects seem to make big trouble.

Now to the conclusion: Is the game worth it? In my opinion there is a lot of fun and enjoyment to be had in this game, especially when you have 3 other to people to play and talk with in Skype or Teamspeak. It is easy to learn, but hard to master(I normally hate these sayings, but when it's true I can't help it). So even if you are not that good at the game, you might be able to get your enjoyment out of it.
The only thing, people might be turned off by is the graphics, but in my opinion this game is a case of gameplay beating graphics in terms of making a joyful experience.
The price is 12‚Ç¨ or your regional equivalent. Buying a 4 or a 2 pack is even more recommended, because of the reasons that are stated above.

The idea of a competetive sports game isn't that uncommon. In the early days there was Windjammers. A discthrowing 1v1 pong-like game in a form of a fightinggame with different specialmoves and characters.
This game on the other hand takes those Ideas and give them a new look and feel and resembles one of the most unique games of this decade.


#### What are we doing exactly? #####
The goal of the game is getting a ball to hit your opponents. You can hit the ball in many directions and the ball is bouncing of the walls. There are different attacks and specials you can do to speed up the ball or causing it to change directions.

####### Gameplay ######
Smooth as butter. Easy to learn, hard to master. You can get relatively far with just playing with feel and a little bit random button presses. But if you learn how to combo, parry and reducing your hitlag, you can get constant wins.

####### Graphics #######
The graphics are completely 2D. It looks like it was done by MS Paint, but it has its own funky style. The graphics are snappy and look good. Especially the effects when you hit the ball as it reaches the speeds of  max 1000000pixel/s (I think thats the speedindex)

####### Balance ########
The game seems to be well balanced. Every character is different and has a specialattack and peculiarities like walljump, doublejump, wallclinging and driving across the ceiling with a skateboard. Also the angles, in which the ball flies after a hit, are different aswell. Because it is more about how you handle the ball, i don't think there will be overpowered characters.

####### Network ########
The netcode is powered by ggpo. You can feel how good the netcode is.. even with 4 players it's smooth as hell. There are some hickups, witch result in disconnects, but considering the age of the game, I wouldn't be surprised if the game got some updates to fix this. After all it's just a little annoyance, which is forgotten after you desperately try to reconnect to the massive fun. (which is fast anyway)

###### Conclusion ######
The game is a must-have. The fun we had in just 6 hours was tremendous. The game is best played with 4 players, in a 2v2 teammatch.
